newsitem.title: USA: Existing homes sales fall sharply in December.
newsitem.headline: Existing homes sales fall sharply in December.

text.p: Brutal winter weather contributed to a sharp drop in home sales last month, though sales of existing homes still set a record for the year, a real estate agents' group said Monday.

The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing homes fell 3.5 percent in December to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.87 million, from a revised rate of 4.01 million in November. The December total was lower than the rate of 4 million forecast by Wall Street economists.
For all of 1996, sales rose 7.5 percent to a record 4.09 million, beating the previous record of 3.99 million homes sold in 1978.
The group said snowstorms in the West caused much of December's decline. Sales also fell in the the Midwest and South. Sales in the Northeast improved.
Industry officials and analysts said December's drop was weather-related, and that the results were still respectable after a strong November.
"In general, the market is as strong now as it was a year ago," association President Russell Booth said. "Consumers often avoid moving in the winter months."
"I think we will probably need another month of activity to see how big the weather factor was," said economist John Bailey at Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette.
The association estimated that existing home sales this year would probably mirror December's annual sales rate, which would mean a drop of about 5 percent from last year's record.
The group's chief economist, John Tuccillo, said the jump in home sales last year reflected improved consumer sentiment that was likely to continue in 1997, though demand would probably slacken.
"The psychological-driven demand has been pretty much used up so that it is not going to be there during 1997 to bolster the housing market," he told reporters.
Despite the expected drop this year, the overall market should remain strong by historical standards, he added.
Last month's sales rate was equal to the pace in December 1995, just before sales accelerated in early 1996 and remained strong despite a slight rise in mortgage rates for much of the year.
Thirty-year, fixed-rate mortgage loans averaged 7.60 percent in December, down from 7.62 percent in November, but up from 7.20 percent in December 1995.
Analysts said a rise in housing prices and a sharp drop in the number of homes available also pointed to resilient strength in the market for existing homes.
The median price -- half of homes sold above the median price and half below -- rose to $118,800 in December from $117,400 in November. The average price rose to $147,100 from $144,200.
The supply of homes fell to 5.1 months from 6.7 months in November. It was the lowest level since December 1995.
"I'm encouraged when I look at prices and the supply of homes," said Anthony Chan at Banc One.
Sales fell 7.7 percent in the West, 4.1 percent in the South and 3.8 percent in the Midwest. Sales in the Northeast rose 5.1 percent.
Previously, the group reported November sales at an annual rate of 4.04 million but revised that to 4.01 million.
